sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Postoperative nausea and vomiting: 5-15 mg IM every 4 hr; the total daily dose should not exceed 60 mg/day
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting: 1 mg IV as needed; total daily dose should not exceed 3 mg/day
  • Schizophrenia: 60 mg IM as needed; the total daily dose should not exceed 150 mg/day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Safety and efficacy not established for children younger than 2.5 years of age
  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting: children 2.5 yr and older, 0.2 to 0.25 mg/kg IM; the total daily dose should not exceed 10 mg/day
  • Schizophrenia: children 2.5 yr and older, 0.2 to 0.25 mg/kg IM; the total daily dose should not exceed 10 mg/day

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Debilitated patients: use 50% of the usual dosage
  • Geriatrics: use 50% of the usual adult dosage

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to triflupromazine products or other phenothiazines
  • Reye's syndrome

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use of anticholinergic drugs
  • concomitant use of other CNS depressant drugs
  • do not withdraw abruptly
  • epileptic patients (can lower the convulsive threshold)
  • history of neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • patients who are exposed to extreme heat or organophosphate insecticides
  • patients with severe cardiovascular or respiratory disease

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Triflupromazine: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypotension, Peripheral edema
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation
  • Neurologic:Akathisia, Dystonia, Somnolence
  • Ophthalmic:Blurred vision, Finding of lacrimation
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Electrocardiogram abnormal
  • Dermatologic:Erythroderma
  • Hematologic:Agranulocytosis, Leukopenia
  • Immunologic:Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Neurologic:Neuroleptic malignant syndrome, Tardive dyskinesia
  • Reproductive:Priapism
  • Respiratory:Respiratory arrest

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• blood pressure during initiation of therapy
  • CBC during at initiation of therapy, then regularly at 6 month intervals
  • liver function tests during initiation of therapy, then regularly at 6-month intervals
  • early signs of neurological complications
  • ophthalmic examinations should be conducted regularly during long-term therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may impair heat regulation. Advise patient to use caution with activities leading to an increased core temperature, such as strenuous exercise, exposure to extreme heat, or dehydration.
  • This drug may cause anticholinergic effects, hypotension, diminished sweating, akathisia, tardive dyskinesia (jerky muscle movements, tongue thrusting, facial grimacing/ticks, random movements of extremities) or nasal congestion.
  • Patient should avoid taking anticholinergic drugs or other CNS depressants concurrently with this drug.
